title: Affective Data Visualisation: Get Your Puppy A Dog Leash
text:
The Affective Version Data Visualisation as promotion material to encourage dog owners to get their puppies a dog leash.





The “Normal” Version Data Visualisation as promotion material to encourage dog owners to get their puppies a dog leash.


In this pair of data visualisations, an affective design method: Metaphorical Imagery was applied.
The only difference in these two visualisation is that the affective version has the background image. In this background image, the actual dog leash was in line with the plot line, metaphorically representing the drop in injury and death rate if more dog owners are using dog leash. 

Development Process

For the “normal” version of this data visualisation, I used R studio to generate the plot:

#png("dogleash.png", width = 600, height = 600, bg = "transparent")

par(mar=c(5,5,5,5), bg="white", pin= c(2.8,2))

xnum <- c(45.5, 51.3, 57.8, 62.4, 70, 76.9)
ynum <- c(7.3, 6.2, 6, 5.5, 4.9, 3.6)


plot(xnum, ynum, type = "o", col = "red", lwd = 2,
     xlab = "Percentage of dog owners using DOG LEASH", 
     ylab = "Annual rate of injury or death of puppies", 
     main = "Buy a DOG LEASH, \n Keep your puppy safe.",
     xlim=c(45,80), ylim = c(3, 7.5), yaxs = "i", yaxt = "n", xaxt="n",
     cex.lab=0.8)

axis(2, at = seq(3, 7.5, by = 1), labels = paste0(seq(3, 7.5, by = 1), "%"), las=2, cex.axis=0.8)

axis(1, at = seq(45,80, by = 5), labels = paste0(seq(45,80, by=5), "%"), cex.axis=0.8)


segments (42.5,7.3,45.5,7.3,lty = 2)
segments(45.5,7.3,45.5,3,lty = 2)
segments(76.9,3.6,76.9,3,lty = 2)
segments(42.5,3.6, 76.9, 3.6, lty = 2)

text(xnum[1], 2.9, labels = paste0(xnum[1], "%"), pos = 1, col = "blue", cex = 0.9,xpd=T)  
text(44, ynum[1], labels = paste0(ynum[1], "%"), pos = 2, col = "blue", cex = 0.9,xpd=T)  
text(xnum[length(xnum)], 2.9, labels = paste0(xnum[length(xnum)], "%"), pos = 1, col = "blue", cex = 0.9,xpd=T)  
text(44, ynum[length(ynum)], labels = paste0(ynum[length(ynum)], "%"), pos = 2, col = "blue", cex = 0.9,xpd=T) 
#dev.off()





For the affective version, I drew the background image and then used PhotoShop to combine them together.

title: Welcome to The Affective Data Visualisation Design Space
text:
Data Visualisations Under Examination, adopted from: What Makes a Visualization Memorable?(Borkin et al.,2013) )



Introduction to Affective Data Visualisation Research

The idea of “emotional appeals in visualisation” (Kostelnick, 2016), “affects/pathos in visualisations” (Campbell, 2018) or “affective visualisations” (Gough, de Berigny Wall and Bednarz, 2014) are emerging in recent years. Those concepts have been used in studying the objectivity / subjectivity of visualisations, the effectiveness of certain visual elements and et cetera.
With all those concepts and researches scattered in different areas related to visualisations, Lan, Wu and Cao (2024) have conducted a systematic review of the existing researches. Within their review, one thread takes my attention: emotion as a result of visualization design.
In this project, Affective Data Visualisation is defined as data visualisation that are able to conveyance messages with the help of emotions and will be put under examination that whether and how they affect the effectiveness of message.
As for the research question, I want to test if affective design is also helpful in the marketing / promotion scenario, since no research has been on this till now (August 2024).

Research Method


Research Question

With literature review, three main methods are identified to be most likely to be effective as affective data visualisation methods:

Zoom-in (Personalised) Design 
Affective Colour Scheme 
Realistic / Metaphorical Imagery 

To test whether those methods are effective when applied to marketing / promotion scenario, I designed several pairs of affective / non-affective (“normal”) data visualisations and conducted an AB test through interview.
As for the aspects to test if the affective data visualisation is effective, three main aspects are indentified through literature review:

Message conveyance 
Audience Engagement 
Call to Action 


Interview Structure

For the interview, the audience will be either shown the three “normal” version of data visualisations or the three affective ones. Each of the data visualisations will be shown will questions asked.

Before the visualisation shown, the participant will be asked about their interest level of the topic of the visualisation (score from 1-5).
The visualisation will be shown for 20 seconds.
The visualisation will be hidden, and the participant will be asked if certain numbers are in line with the visualisation / certain messages are conveyed with the visualisation.
The visualisation will be shown again, then the participant will be asked to what extent they agree that now they understand more about the topic (score from 1-5).
The participant will be asked about their interest level on the topic now (score from 1-5).
The participant will be asked about to what extent they are more likely to take action (either consider more before next purchase or directly purchase) after viewing the visualisation (score from 1-5).

This process will be repeated with all three visualisations. Then, with all visualisations hidden, participant will be asked to tell if certain numbers / claims are in line with these visualisations.
With these steps, all three aspects of effectiveness of affective data visualisation will be tested:



Interview Structure

title: Affective Data Visualisation: Which Loaf to Buy?
text:
The Affective Version Data Visualisation as marketing material of a multi-grain bread loaf.





The “Normal” Version Data Visualisation as marketing material of a multi-grain bread loaf.


In this pair of data visualisations, I applied two methods formerly identified in my research: Personalised Design and Realistic / Metaphorical Imagery.
Meanwhile, I applied the same colour code and descriptive annotations. With this method, the aim is to rule out the effects of words and colours (which can also be a method of affective design).
As for the application of personalised design, it was achieved by adding the healthy-looking human figure grabbing breads to enhance personal connection with the audience who are looking for bread and a healthier life through a multi-grain loaf.
For realistic / metaphorical Imagery, I applied realistic imagery by using the actual photo of different amounts of grains to show the percentage of grains contained in the loaf. 

Development Process

For the affective version, I found this original photo from a website and re-purposed it as a marketing material with some PhotoShop work.




Original Picture





Final Result



As for the “normal” version, i used R in Rstudio to generate the following plots:

grainlabel <- c("Sesame", "Sunflower", "Flaxseed", "Rye", "Wheat", "Barley")
graincolor <- c("#F0E68C", "#C4A484", "#8B5A2B", "#A0522D", "#F5DEB3", "#BDB76B")
A.val <- c(10, 15, 15, 20, 20, 0)
B.val <- c(0, 0, 15, 85, 0, 0)
C.val <- c(0, 15, 15, 0, 0, 70)


PIE.val <- cbind(A.val, B.val, C.val)

# dev.new()

par(mfcol = c(2, 3), bg = "lightgrey")  


for (i in 1:3) {
  
  labels <- ifelse(PIE.val[, i] > 0, grainlabel, "")
  
  par(mar = c(0, 3, 0, 3))
  

  pie(PIE.val[, i], labels = rep("", length(labels)),
      col = graincolor, border = TRUE , radius = 1)
  

  angles <- cumsum(c(0, PIE.val[, i])) / sum(PIE.val[, i]) * 2 * pi
  

  label_pos <- angles[-length(angles)] + diff(angles) / 2
  

  text(x = 1* cos(label_pos), y = 1 * sin(label_pos), 
       labels = labels, cex = 1.2, col = "black",font = 2)
  
  par(mar = c(5, 3, 2, 2))  

  bp <- barplot(PIE.val[, i], col = graincolor, ylim = c(0, max(PIE.val)), 
                names.arg = grainlabel,  
                las = 2,  
                yaxt = "n"  
  )
  

  y_ticks <- pretty(c(0, max(PIE.val)))  
  y_labels <- paste(y_ticks, "%", sep = "")
  

  axis(2, at = y_ticks, labels = y_labels, las = 2, cex.axis= 0.8)
  

  percent_labels <- paste(PIE.val[, i], "%", sep = "")
  

  text(x = bp, y = PIE.val[, i], label = percent_labels, pos = 3, cex = 0.65, col = "black")
}




 Then with bit more PhotoShop, i have the “normal” version of the data visualisation that contains all the same information as the affective one.



The “Normal” Version Data Visualisation of marketing material of a multi-grain bread loaf.

title: Affective Data Visualisation: Fancy A Chunk of Chocolate Bar?
text:
The Affective Version Data Visualisation as promotion material of a fair-trade chocolate bar.





The “Normal” Version Data Visualisation as promotion material of a fair-trade chocolate bar.


In this pair of data visualisations, two methods formerly identified in my research are combined and applied: Affective Colour Scheme and Realistic / Metaphorical Imagery.
In the affective version of the visualisation, the different amount of chunks of a chocolate bar is designed to represent the percentage of profit acquired by different stakeholders of the chocolate industry. The chunk of chocolate bar is a realistic imagery (also in Affective Colour Scheme because of the realistic chocolate-like colour) that connect the represented data to real life. 

Development Process

For both versions, I used R and Rstudio to generate the graphs first and then used PhotoShop to tune them into format of promotion materials.
For the affective version, I used loops to draw the chocolate bar with chunks of different colours:

title: Research Results
text:
Research Result



Interview Result

The comparison between the affective and non-affective versions of the data visualisations revealed notable differences across the three aspects: message conveyance, audience engagement, and ability to call to action.
In terms of message conveyance, participants viewing the affective versions were able to grasp a greater number of messages compared to those viewing the non-affective versions. In the test result, the audience of the affective version got a 6.9% higher rate of identifying whether certain message is conveyed through the visualisation. However, they were less accurate in recalling if specific numerical data is right (a -5.8% rate of identifying is certain number is mentioned in the visualisation), suggesting that while emotions helped in conveying general ideas, precise details were more challenging to retain. Participants also reported a deeper overall understanding of the topics after viewing the affective visualisations. To be more detailed, the audience of the affective version report a 75% average score of agreeing that then know more about the topic after viewing the data visualisations, while the percentage is 54% for the “normal” version.
Regarding audience engagement, participants exposed to the affective designs exhibited a higher increase (11.4% more increase) in interest in the topic, as reflected in their post-visualisation interest scores. Furthermore, they were able to recall more general messages from the visualisations (5.6% more), although there was no significant difference in the number of specific data points remembered between the two groups (-0.9% in accuracy).
Finally, in terms of ability to call to action, participants were expressing a higher intention (3.5% more likely) to act (whether considering further or making a direct purchase) after viewing the affective visualisations. This suggests that the emotional elements incorporated into the designs may be more persuasive in motivating audience behaviour than the non-affective versions.

Summary

Overall, the results indicate that affective data visualisations are more effective compared to non-affective ones in a marketing or promotional context. They not only enhance the conveyance of messages and foster a deeper understanding of the topic but also significantly increase audience engagement and interest. Additionally, affective visualisations demonstrate greater potential in motivating the audience to take action, making them a valuable tool in promoting products or ideas. These findings suggest that incorporating emotional elements into data visualisation design can enhance both the communicative and persuasive power of the visual content.
